message.content: This question requires knowledge about the phenomenon of fogging up on a reflective surface. When a reflective surface like a mirror or a window fog up, it is because water vapor in the air comes into contact with the cool surface and condenses into water droplets. This is known as condensation. Option (A) is incorrect because reflection refers to the bouncing back of light waves. Option (B) is incorrect because refraction refers to the bending of light waves as they pass through different mediums. Option (C) is incorrect because evaporation refers to the process of liquid turning into a gas, not the reverse.

This question requires basic knowledge about the physical process of fogging up on a reflective surface. When a reflective surface fogs up, it is due to the process of condensation. Condensation occurs when warm, moist air comes into contact with a cooler surface, causing the water vapor in the air to turn into liquid droplets. Option (A) is incorrect because reflection refers to the bouncing of light off a surface. Option (B) is incorrect because refraction refers to the bending of light as it passes through different mediums. Option (C) is incorrect because evaporation refers to the process of liquid turning into vapor.

The moisture in the air comes into contact with the cooler surface and condenses into droplets, causing the fogging effect. Option (A) is incorrect because reflection refers to the bouncing off of light waves by a surface, not the fogging up of a surface. Option (B) is incorrect because refraction refers to the bending of light as it passes through a different medium, and is not related to fogging. Option (C) is incorrect because evaporation refers to the process of a liquid turning into a gas, not the fogging up of a surface.
